content.user_title: Turn Ideas into Validated Designs Through Dialogue
content.value_statement: Brainstorming often leads to incomplete specs that cause rework. This skill guides Claude Code through a structured process to explore requirements, evaluate alternatives, and create validated designs before implementation.
actual_capabilities: Guides structured requirement gathering through one question at a time
Presents multiple design approaches with trade-offs and recommendations
Breaks complex designs into digestible sections for incremental validation
Documents validated designs to markdown files with proper naming conventions
Integrates with git workflow for design documentation and implementation planning
limitations: Requires human interaction for question answering and validation
Does not generate code or implementation, only design documentation
Effectiveness depends on user engagement in the collaborative process
References optional skills that may not be available in all environments

use_cases.title: Feature Planning for Product Teams
use_cases.description: Product managers work with Claude Code to explore new feature ideas, evaluate technical approaches, and create validated design documents before passing to engineering teams.

use_cases.title: Architecture Design for Greenfield Projects
use_cases.description: Engineers use the skill to systematically explore architectural options, document trade-offs, and arrive at validated technical designs before writing code.

use_cases.title: Refactoring Strategy Development
use_cases.description: Development teams collaborate with Claude Code to analyze existing systems, explore refactoring approaches, and document migration strategies with clear success criteria.
use_cases.target_user: Engineering teams working on legacy systems

prompt_templates.title: Basic Feature Brainstorming
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to add user authentication to my application. Can you help me brainstorm the design?
prompt_templates.scenario: Starting point for exploring a new feature idea

prompt_templates.title: Refactoring Exploration
prompt_templates.prompt: Our payment processing code is getting messy. Help me brainstorm a cleaner architecture that handles multiple payment providers.

prompt_templates.title: Complex System Design
prompt_templates.prompt: We need to build a real-time notification system that scales to millions of users. Walk me through designing this from scratch.

prompt_templates.title: Integration Planning
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to integrate our app with Stripe and PayPal. Help me design an abstraction layer that makes it easy to add more payment providers later.

output_examples.input: Help me design a caching layer for our API
output_examples.output:
I've reviewed your project structure. Let me start by understanding your requirements.

What's the primary goal for this caching layer?

A) Reduce database load from repeated queries
B) Speed up response times for end users
C) Handle rate limiting from external APIs
D) Multiple goals from above

output_examples.input: We chose option A - reduce database load
output_examples.output:
Based on your requirements, here are three approaches:

**Recommended: Redis-based distributed cache**
Use Redis as a shared cache layer. This works well because your app already runs multiple instances. Redis handles TTL automatically and provides atomic operations for cache invalidation.

**Alternative 1: In-memory application cache**
Simpler to set up, but each app instance has its own cache, leading to redundant database queries and memory usage.

**Alternative 2: Database query result caching**
PostgreSQL materialized views. Lower latency but less flexible for invalidation patterns.

Which approach fits your infrastructure and team expertise?

best_practices: Ask one focused question at a time to avoid overwhelming the user
Always present multiple approaches with clear trade-offs before committing to a design
Break design presentations into small sections and validate incrementally rather than dumping complete specs
anti_patterns: Asking multiple questions in one message, forcing users to answer in a structured format
Presenting a single design approach without exploring alternatives or trade-offs
Dumping complete technical specifications without pausing for user validation and feedback

faq.question: Does this skill write code or only documentation?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on creating design documentation through collaborative brainstorming. It documents validated designs to markdown files but does not generate implementation code. You can optionally continue to implementation using referenced skills.

faq.question: Can I use this skill without the referenced optional skills?
faq.answer: Yes, the core brainstorming process works independently. References to elements-of-style, superpowers:using-git-worktrees, and superpowers:writing-plans are optional enhancements that improve documentation quality and implementation workflow if available.

faq.question: How is this different from just asking Claude Code to design something?
faq.answer: This skill provides a structured methodology: one question at a time, multiple choice options, incremental validation, and mandatory exploration of alternatives. This prevents common pitfalls like incomplete requirements or jumping to solutions too quickly.

faq.question: What happens to the design documents created?
faq.answer: Designs are saved to docs/plans/ with date-prefixed filenames and committed to git. This creates a historical record of design decisions and allows teams to reference the reasoning behind architectural choices.

faq.question: Can this skill help with refactoring existing code?
faq.answer: Yes, it works for both greenfield and refactoring projects. The skill starts by understanding current project context through files, documentation, and commit history before exploring design options.

faq.question: How long does a typical brainstorming session take?
faq.answer: Session length varies based on complexity and how many questions are needed to clarify requirements. Simple features may take 5-10 exchanges, while complex system designs could require 20-30 exchanges for thorough exploration.
